pullRequest.body:
Given a module over a topological ring, we define the action topology on this module to be the finest module making it into a topological module (i.e. the finest topology making addition and scalar multiplication continuous).

NB this PR gave rise to a discussion about whether `⨆ a ∈ s, f a` or `sSup (f '' s)` should be the simp normal form, which was discussed on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/normal.20form.20for.20pullback.20of.20Inf.20of.20topologies/near/472676441) without any clear conclusion.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

I wanted this because for a finite free module it can be checked to be the product topology, and for an algebra over a commutative topological ring which is finite as a module, multiplication in the algebra is automatically continuous with this topology. I have all of these results in the FLT repo [in this file](https://github.com/ImperialCollegeLondon/FLT/blob/main/FLT/ForMathlib/ActionTopology.lean). What inspired me to PR it to mathlib was Yael's question [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Topology.20on.20a.20finite.20dimensional.20vector.20space/near/469687218) -- this topology gives a very nice answer to that question.

nodes.body:
### PR summary [753646ea1a](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16895/commits/753646ea1a9d0d037615ada39465ff041065c740)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Module.Action`|1014|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ ActionTopology.continuousAdd`
`+ ActionTopology.continuousSMul`
`+ IsActionTopology`
`+ IsActionTopology.toContinuousAdd`
`+ IsActionTopology.toContinuousSMul`
`+ actionTopology`
`+ actionTopology_le`
`+ coinduced_sSup`
`+ eq_actionTopology`
`+ induced_sInf`
`+ instSubsingleton`
`+ instance _root_.TopologicalSemiring.toIsActionTopology : IsActionTopology R R`
`+ instance _root_.TopologicalSemiring.toOppositeIsActionTopology : IsActionTopology Rᵐᵒᵖ R`
`+ iso`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

```suggestion
* `ActionTopology.instSelf : IsActionTopology R R`. The action topology on `R` is `R`'s topology.
```

```suggestion
instance IsActionTopology.toContinuousSMul [TopologicalSpace A] [IsActionTopology R A] :
```
(and below for `ContinuousAdd`)

This is a proof type, so
```suggestion
  eq_actionTopology' : τA = actionTopology R A
```
Does this also work as `(gc_coinduced_induced f).l_sSup` or similar?

Annoyingly, no:
```
type mismatch
  GaloisConnection.l_sSup (gc_coinduced_induced g)
has type
  TopologicalSpace.coinduced g (sSup s) = ⨆ a ∈ s, TopologicalSpace.coinduced g a : Prop
but is expected to have type
  TopologicalSpace.coinduced g (sSup s) = sSup (TopologicalSpace.coinduced g '' s) : Prop
```
This works: `  rw [(gc_coinduced_induced f).l_sSup, sSup_image]`. Your comment made me realise I was using g instead of f though (i.e. I'd switched the roles of alpha and beta compared to the other lemmas), I've now fixed that. I don't even need this lemma, I only added it because I needed `induced_sInf` and I imagined that people would ask for the dual result in review.

I think the issue here is that we can't agree whether `⨆ a ∈ s, f a` or `sSup (f '' s)` is the preferred spelling, and so the library lemma uses the first and yours uses the second. I think @urkud prefers the former, but I'd argue that having `sSup` on both sides of the equality is more important, so I prefer the latter.

So are you arguing for `GaloisConnection.l_sSup'` with your preferred spelling? And should this be a separate PR? I am quite happy to dump this lemma completely in this PR, it's unused, it's only there for symmetry's sake.

The Zulip discussion [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/normal.20form.20for.20pullback.20of.20Inf.20of.20topologies/near/472676441) seems to indicate that what I'm doing here is fine.
I was just about to ask for these, but I guess I don't need to. Leaving them to a future PR is fine!
I figured 250 lines was plenty for the PR of the definition (about 50% of them are comments though!)

```suggestion
* The action topology is a functor from the category of `R`-modules
```
for markdown rendering

```suggestion
and `A` is an `R`-algebra of finite type as `R`-module, then `A` with its action
```

```suggestion
* The action topology is a functor from the category of `R`-modules
  to the category of topological `R`-modules, and it's an adjoint to the forgetful functor.
```

```suggestion
theorem eq_actionTopology [τA : TopologicalSpace A] [IsActionTopology R A] :
```
Oh yes -- thanks.
Should this be in the `Topology` or `TopologicalSpace` namespace? cc @urkud, @YaelDillies .
No strong opinion here

```suggestion
  /-- Note that this should not be used directly, and `eq_actionTopology`, which takes `R` and `A` explicitly, should be used instead. -/
  eq_actionTopology' : τA = actionTopology R A
```

```suggestion
namespace IsActionTopology
```

```suggestion
instance _root_.TopologicalSemiring.toIsActionTopology (R : Type*) [Semiring R] [τR : TopologicalSpace R] [TopologicalSemiring R] :
```
can you add the `MulOpposite` action too?

Do you mean "prove `IsActionTopology R Rᵐᵒᵖ`? Or more generally "prove `IsActionTopology R M -> IsActionTopology R Mᵐᵒᵖ`? The simplest way to do this would be to deduce it from the fact that `M` and  `Mᵐᵒᵖ` are ContinuousLinearEquiv, and then it follows immediately from the results in this PR. However we don't seem to have this result; we have that they're isomorphic as R-modules and that they're homeomorphic, but we don't have the `ContinuousLinearEquiv`. Do you want me to make a new file adding only this result? In this PR? Or did I misunderstand?
I think you are misunderstanding. Eric is not talking about opposing the `M` but opposing the `R` instead

... and this really cannot be deduced from the `R R` version because the action is different (and incompatible with the identification of `R` with `R^mop`)

In general, if you can talk about `a * b`, then you can try talking about `a • b` or about `op b • a`. Currently, you have done the first but not the second.

If this is what Eric means then my comments above still apply, you just replace R with Rᵐᵒᵖ and Rᵐᵒᵖ with R (i.e. deduce it from the fact that Rᵐᵒᵖ has the action topology as a module over Rᵐᵒᵖ rather than the fact that R has the action topology as a module over R). So if my current understanding of what I'm being asked to do is correct, one solution would be to make a new file containing one result

```lean
import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.Opposites
import Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Module.Basic

variable (R : Type*) [Semiring R] [τR : TopologicalSpace R] [TopologicalSemiring R]
  {M : Type*} [AddCommMonoid M] [Module R M] [TopologicalSpace M] [ContinuousSMul R M]

def MulOpposite.opContinuousLinearEquiv : M ≃L[R] Mᵐᵒᵖ where
  __ := MulOpposite.opLinearEquiv R
```

(because that surely doesn't go in this file), and then in this file we add

```lean
instance mulOpposite (R : Type*) [Semiring R] [TopologicalSpace R] [TopologicalSemiring R] :
    IsActionTopology Rᵐᵒᵖ R := .iso (MulOpposite.opContinuousLinearEquiv Rᵐᵒᵖ).symm
```

An alternative approach is to put `MulOpposite.opContinuousLinearEquiv` into `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Module.Basic` and add `import Mathlib.Algebra.Module.Opposites` to that file (of length >= 2400 lines).

Thoughts?
But surely `R` isn't `R`-linearly isomorphic to `Rᵐᵒᵖ`?
Do we secretly have a diamond where `op a • op b` is both `op (b * a)` and `op (a * b)` depending on the instance you're inferring?

I slightly suspect [`MulOpposite.instMulAction`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Action/Opposite.html#MulOpposite.instMulAction) which defines `a • op b := op (a • b)` is the issue
I'm not really following this discussion, but I pushed a commit with the sorry filled.

nit:
```suggestion
    TopologicalSpace.induced g (sInf s) = sInf (TopologicalSpace.induced g '' s) := by
```
and below

I think this should be the definition; namely, `IsActionTopology` should mean "the canonical map from `WithActionTopology R` to `R` is continuous", where `WithActionTopology R` is a type synonym that puts the action topology on `R`.

This should eliminate all the `@`s below!
I tried this out in eric-wieser/withActionTopology, but there's a little more boilerplate needed than expected.

pullRequest.title: feat: topology on module over topological ring
